intro: Sida cearensis, commonly known as Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant features alternate, ovate leaves with hairy surfaces and produces small, pale yellow flowers. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes other plants like cotton and hibiscus. Sida cearensis is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of environmental conditions.
